Summary Skill Summary: 
 
•Ph. D. in Polymer Chemistry, with honors. 
 
•Eight years of R&D experience in polymer synthesis and characterization, including: Biopolymers, Thermoplastics, ionic polymers, silicon polymers, electrochemically active polymers, functionalized surface coatings, custom atomic layer polymerization, and film deposition. 
 
•Excellent analytical skills (Analytical Chemist Award): Experienced in the characterization of new materials by HPLC, DSC, SEM, FT-IR, UV/VIS, including polymer process/ property relationships. 
 
•Equipment experience: Rebuilding polymerization reactors, troubleshooting, maintaining analytical equipment, and adhering to GLP’s and SOP’s.  
 
•Experience with Statistical Process Controls (SPC), Design of Experiments (DOE), and Analysis of Variance (ANOVA). 
 
•Excellent communication of complex topics: Over a dozen awards for creativity, presentation, and leadership, with five publications in peer reviewed journals, and experience preparing US patents to protect intellectual property. 
 
•Skilled in cross-discipline project leadership: Experience working with chemists, physicists, material and surface scientists, engineers, test groups, business management, legal counsel, and academics. 
 
•Experience ramping up from development scale to high volume production: Includes preparing technology transfer packages, training manufacturing technicians, qualifying and statistically matching multiple tools in a set.  
 
•Demonstrated success in generating new ideas and products:  
1) Development of fundamental concepts 
 
2) Enabling the concept through chemical synthesis 
 
3) Proof of concept though material characterization/  
device fabrication

Summary With over 13 years of professional experience, I have held positions ranging from senior-level process engineer to supply chain management. I am well-versed in supplier relationship management, commercial responsibilities, high-volume manufacturing environments and technology development. 
 
The advantage I can bring to any company is that I can be both technical and commercial, which allows me to sift through situations with logic and acumen to arrive to an optimal solution.  
 
Specialties:  
-APICS CSCP 
-Supply Chain Management: Management of global suppliers for test industry with regular travel to Asia 
-Complex global agreements covering aggressive T&C's, pricing and IP ownership 
-Embedded Packaging: Wet systems and dry film resist lamination, Design of Experiments (DOEs), Technical Mentor, Ops and PM specs 
-Business-to-Business Sales: Global account management with domestic and international sales transactions

June 2015  – Present (3 months) Phoenix, Arizona Area Field Service Manager responsible for a talented team of 15 Field Service Engineers (FSE's) to support semiconductor customers (I/C, opto-electronic, LED) in North America.  
 Supply Chain Manager Intel Corporation November 2011  –  May 2015  (3 years 7 months) Chandler, AZ Supply Chain Manager overseeing global supply chain for Test Capital Equipment.  
 
Accomplishments include: 
 
-Partnered with R&D and Factory engineering to manage demand forecasts, pricing and lead-time for NPIs and CPIs to support product roadmap timelines. 
 
-Managed global suppliers (contract manufacturers, niche suppliers) to deliver to affordability and velocity goals.  
 
-Generated risk mitigation plans for potential insolvent/financially high-risk suppliers of several commodities. 
 
-Negotiated a contract valued at $2M-$3M in spends as well as ongoing capital/expense improvements to achieve fair pricing. 
 
-Closed agreements involving complex IP ownership and collaboration efforts. Senior Process Development Engineer Intel Corporation July 2010  –  November 2011  (1 year 5 months) Chandler, AZ Engineer developing a process for die-embedding technology incorporating fab processing and packaging methodologies. 
 
Accomplishments include: 
-Successfully managed the installation and qualification of circuit board equipment such as acid-pretreatment, dry film resist lamination and etch modules.  
 
-Conducted Design of Experiments (DOE's) to characterize lithography and wet process items. 
 
-Managed Operations and Preventative Maintenance (PM) specs as well as exclusively orcehstrated PM schedules, tasks and procedures. Technical Sales Analyst Intel Resale Corporation April 2008  –  July 2010  (2 years 4 months) Chandler, AZ Sales analyst with a technical background that managed accounts to sell 200mm and 300mm equipment while serving as a technical resource to other sales analysts. 
 
Accomplishments include: 
-Interacted with global customers comprising of end users (OEM's and chip manufacturers), refurbishers and brokers.  
 
-Developed the 300mm used equipment business strategy. Duties included a SWOT analysis, pricing strategy and business development in emerging markets, especially in Asia. 
 
-Conducted business-to-business sales to help achieve an annual sales revenue of $86.2 M in 2008 and $31.4 M in 2009. 
 
-Single-handedly initiated, negotiated and closed a $1.25 M deal to a Taiwanese foundry, which was the first of its kind for the company. Senior Lithography Process Engineer Intel Corporation June 2001  –  March 2008  (6 years 10 months) Chandler, AZ Tool owner for TEL ACT 8 Clean Tracks for 130nm node and TEL Lithius Clean Tracks as well as Nikon S205 Scanners in 65nm node technology. 
 
Accomplishments include: 
-Completed a factory start-up for Intel's first 300mm High-Volume manufacturing. In doing so, amazing yield results were obtained at RISO 679. 
 
-Performed a Defect Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) as a defect reduction measure. Defect density in 300mm lithography was reduced by 80% and by 30% in 200mm lithography for blocked etch defects. 
 
-Conducted cost savings projects such as reduced resist consumption in 300mm technology and second sourcing amine filters along with virtual factory tool re-use in 200mm technology. 	Plasma Processing in Semiconductor Nanofabrication Senior Process Development Engineer Intel Corporation October 2005  –  March 2009  (3 years 6 months) Portland, Oregon, USA 	Developed 45nm node plasma etching process for the isolation section in FEOL and transferred it successfully to High Volume Manufacture HVM 
	Developed the 32nm node plasma etch process for the isolation section in FEOL 
	Developed Real-time Feedback Control of plasma processes using Advanced Process Control (APC) based on non-intrusive Optical Emission Spectroscopy (OES) diagnostic and spectra reduction using Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Multivariate Analysis 
	Designed, ran, and evaluated complex research and engineering experiments in the area of dry plasma etching for semiconductor fabrication.  
	Was responsible for identifying the processing conditions, which will best achieve the device design goals 
	Sustained manufacturing, monitored and improved process capability (Cp, Cpk) 
	Interacted closely with other patterning groups (litho and metrology), Process Integration, Manufacturing Engineering, and Plasma Etch Vendors to ensure successful qualification of dry etch processes.  
	Provided skill training and technical direction to peers.  
	Operated with considerable freedom on short and long range projects requiring judgment. Research Assistant University of Wisconsin-Madison January 1999  –  September 2005  (6 years 9 months) Madison, Wisconsin Area Graduate work was mainly focused in trying to understand the mechanism of generating Superthermal electrons in HSX during the Electron Cyclotron Resonance Heating (ECRH) discharges, and their confinement in different magnetic configurations. In order to achieve this goal, the Hard X-ray (HXR) emission during ECRH discharges was measured and analyzed. A detection system that fits our experimental needs based upon the following detectors was designed: 
	Si-PIN (manufactured by Amptek), for the range 1 – 30 KeV 
	CdZnTl (eV-280, manufactured by eVproducts), for the range 20 – 300 KeV 
	NaI(Tl) (manufactured by Amptek), for the range 100 KeV - 2 MeV 
A Pulse Height Analysis system based on software (IDL program) and hardware (Amptek MCA8000) to analyze the raw data and obtain the energy spectrum of the HXR was used.  
Other HSX diagnostics were used in this work to better understand the dynamics of Superthermal electrons including: 
	Thomson Scattering for measuring the electron temperature. 
	Microwave interferometer for measuring the plasma density. 
	Diamagnetic Flux Loop for measuring the stored energy. 
	Soft X-ray array to measure the soft x-ray emission. 
	Electron Cyclotron Emission to measure thermal and nonthermal electron Cyclotron Emission during the discharge. 
	Microwave diodes for measuring the microwave power.  
The GENRAY code was used for ray tracing calculations and microwave power deposition, while the CQL3D Fokker-Planck code was used to calculate Superthermal electrons distribution function and HXR spectrum at the detector location. Single Particle Stochastic Heating and Guiding Center Drift Orbits models were developed and used to verify the experimental results. Summary During roles in Process & Product Development & Management in green-tech startups and other high-uncertainty venture environments, Patrick has gained extensive experience with global customer service, technical applications, operations, quality control, device characterization and prototyping of electronic and optical devices. He has developed prototype film-deposition, self-assembly techniques, curing and measurement devices resulting in 4 Patents and ~25 refereed publications, and citations in at least 7 published technical books.  
 
Patrick has developed and improved the material parameters, processes, automation, software controls, yield analysis, statistical analysis, and metrology techniques for a variety of thin-film optical materials on small-scale and large-scale substrates. Coating techniques include electrostatic self-assembly, spin-coating, dip-coating, slot-flow coating, and reverse Gravure-roll coating in conjunction with several cure techniques for polymer, polymer-composite, and sol-gel films. Ranging from 5 nm to 100s of microns, these films have been used in optics and multilayer devices including photovoltaics, photonics, anti-corrosion, diffusion barrier, and electronics encapsulation.

He has developed prototype film-deposition, self-assembly techniques, curing and measurement devices resulting in 4 Patents and ~25 refereed publications, and citations in at least 7 published technical books.  
 
Patrick has developed and improved the material parameters, processes, automation, software controls, yield analysis, statistical analysis, and metrology techniques for a variety of thin-film optical materials on small-scale and large-scale substrates. Coating techniques include electrostatic self-assembly, spin-coating, dip-coating, slot-flow coating, and reverse Gravure-roll coating in conjunction with several cure techniques for polymer, polymer-composite, and sol-gel films. Ranging from 5 nm to 100s of microns, these films have been used in optics and multilayer devices including photovoltaics, photonics, anti-corrosion, diffusion barrier, and electronics encapsulation.
